content:
The triangles in Large Oblique and Validator 8 are not valid, which can be seen in the significant deviation from the equality implied by the Law of Cosines (or you can see that c > a, b and realize that C < 60º is absurd). More pedantically, only the equilateral and right triangles are actually valid.
I suggest increasing the number of significant figures in the input values and ensuring that the answers mod 0.01 are not anywhere near 0.005 to protect CodinGamers from rounding errors. Alternatively, either c or theta should be omitted so that there is there is no possibility of a contradiction between input values.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tout est bon

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This problem is a well-rounded exercise that combines mathematical theory with programming practice, teaching:

Trigonometry and unit conversion.
Formula implementation and precision.
Algorithm design and decomposition.
                                                                                                                                                                            It's a great way to build foundational skills in both mathematics and programming

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting fun maths problem, good for a CoC challenge
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
managed to solve the problem, was very fun :).
I wonder if I should also give the formula for the area of an arbitrary triangle?

You should give all formulas required as the clash of code is a test more on programming skills than on maths knowledge.

Input
* Please add line numbers and variable types to ALL the descriptions, e.g.
<<Line 1>>: A floating point [[a]] for the side length a

Output
* Please move the last sentence to Constraint section.

Constraints
* Please delete the first part of every constraint, i.e. keep only the inequalities.

Thanks.

Wow that's a huge (and should have been obvious) oversight on the last test and Validator. I've updated them to reflect what a true depiction of the test. I also increased the significant figure of theta across all test cases (where relevant). I've adjusted the Large Equilateral (and validator) to allow for better handling of rounding errors as well as the Large Isosceles.

I am however unsure what you mean about only equilateral and right triangles being actually valid. Would love clarification on the matter. Thanks

If the cosine of a rational multiple of pi is nonnegative and rational, it can only be 0, 1/2, or 1, corresponding to a 90º angle, a 60º angle, and a 0º angle, respectively. The inputs are rational numbers, so only these angles can be exact.

Ah I get what you mean, I believe the error in Theta is quite a bit smaller with that additional significant figure and the values (a,b,c) I've chosen also give good tolerance. Thanks again for the feedback.
The precision of theta seems sufficient, as my solution based on Heron's formula now passes. You're welcome for the feedback!
Appreciate the feedback, I've implemented those changes.

Just two more minor points:

Goal
* Please change "a arbitrary" to "an arbitrary".

* Please format "theta" as a [[variable]].

Thanks.
